title: Development, Construction, and Operation of a Multisample Volumetric Apparatus for the Study of Gas Adsorption Equilibrium
abstract: The construction of a simple volumetric adsorption apparatus is highlighted. The setup is inexpensive and provides a clear demonstration of gas phase adsorption concepts. The topic is suitable for undergraduate chemistry and chemical engineering students. Moreover, this unit can also provide quantitative data that can be used by young researchers to screen the adsorption capacity of different adsorbent materials for various gases. A Labview-based interface was developed to allow the students to perform automated data acquisition and unit control. The laboratorial setup permits the simultaneous measurement of gas adsorption equilibrium on two adsorbent samples, up to 20 bar over a wide temperature range (303–1373 K). The quality of the obtained data was validated by comparison with adsorption isotherms recorded on a high-precision gravimetric apparatus. For this purpose, adsorption equilibria of carbon dioxide (CO

) at 323 K were recorded on a commercial sample of metal–organic framework MIL-53(Al) as well as on activated carbon. The recorded data were in good agreement with the data obtained by gravimetry, which suggests the validity of the data produced using the new setup.

Knowledge of the adsorption equilibrium properties of an adsorbent–adsorbate system is determinant for the design of cyclic adsorption processes.

Therefore, it is extremely important that the curricula of future industrial chemistry/chemical engineering graduates include the study of adsorption processes. The chemistry student must be familiar with the experimental procedures used in the determination of adsorption equilibrium data.
The educational interest of adsorption theoretical and experimental aspects has been reported in the chemical education literature,
although little work is devoted to the teaching advantages of using volumetric apparatuses for the measurement of gas-phase adsorption equilibrium.

Therefore, in this work, a new volumetric apparatus for the determination of gas adsorption equilibrium was designed, assembled, and tested. The volumetric setup provides pressure and temperature readings, which allow students to apply simple gas-phase physics in order to determine the amount adsorbed. The apparatus has two adsorption cells to allow the simultaneous recording of adsorption equilibrium on two adsorbent samples. The adsorbents can be activated
up to 1373 K (maximum oven temperature) under vacuum. The operation of the volumetric apparatus was validated by measuring the adsorption isotherms of carbon dioxide (CO

) at 323 K on an activated carbon and on a commercial sample of metal organic framework (MOF) MIL-53(Al). The obtained adsorption equilibrium data were compared with data previously determined by our group, using a high-precision gravimetric unit, in order to assess the good quality of the volumetric apparatus built. This unit was assembled and has been used by students of the Integrated Master of Science in Chemical and Biochemical Engineering program, awarding a Bachelor or a Master of Science (MSc) degree, upon completion of three or five years of the program, respectively. The students employ the unit in their experimental work, as part of their working plan either in the course of Introduction to Scientific Research of the curricula profile or in their MSc dissertations, which give them the insights of fundamental adsorption science and its practice.

The low-cost (approximately 8500 €), multisample volumetric apparatus was designed to allow the simultaneous recording of adsorption equilibrium on two adsorbent samples. The system can be expanded to handle additional samples just by reproducing equivalent sample lines. Inc., USA) on each sample line measure the operation pressure up to 20 bar; an oven (Nabertherm B170 GmbH, Germany) controls the temperature of the adsorption cells over the range of 303–1373 K. The recording of the adsorption isotherms follows the typical methodology in volumetric apparatuses.
The experimental procedure consists of the addition of pressure to the reference volumes (
), and, after pressure and temperature stabilization, the gas supplied is expanded to the cell containing the adsorbent (

). After this step, the system pressure is monitored until the adsorption equilibrium is reached, which is assumed to occur when the rate change of the pressure approaches zero under isothermal conditions, i.e., the pressure variation is lower than 0.01 bar, which is the accuracy of the pressure transducers employed (0.05% of their full scale), over a minimum period of time of 45–60 min. Then, the adsorption cells are once again isolated from the reference volumes, by closing valves SV

, and the method is repeated until enough experimental points to generate the adsorption isotherm are obtained. When the maximum pressure is reached, a similar procedure is repeated, but this time by stepwise depressurization of the reference volumes and subsequent contact with the adsorption cells. This allows checking the existence of hysteresis effects.

In this work, approximately 7 to 12 experimental points were recorded per isotherm. The unit operator must be aware that as the number of collected points increases, the cumulative error becomes significantly larger. For this reason we suggest the acquisition of a maximum of 15 points per isotherm when pressure transducers similar to ours are employed.

The common cautions when working with high-pressure gases must be taken; close supervision of undergraduate students is suggested. Also, the operator must be careful not to damage the pressure transducers by exceeding their operating range.

In summary, the good agreement between the experimental results obtained with the new multisample volumetric unit and the previously existing gravimetric data validates the performance of the unit designed and assembled in our laboratory for chemical education purposes.

The described apparatus and method can be a powerful tool for undergraduate gas adsorption equilibrium studies. This apparatus is frequently applied in the first cycle of the Integrated Master of Science in Chemical and Biochemical Engineering (IMSCBE) program, Bachelor’s level (3 years), namely, in the class of Introduction to Scientific Research, lectured in the Faculdade de Ciências e Tecnologia (FCT) of Universidade Nova de Lisboa (Lisbon, Portugal). The students have contact with, and are involved in, ongoing research and development projects led by FCT lecturers and researchers (FCT currently has 322 students working on projects within this program). Furthermore, the laboratorial unit has been used in the second cycle of the IMSCBE, Master’s level (5 years), specifically in the development of MSc dissertations. The students are asked to employ the apparatus in their experimental work, as part of their classes or dissertation work plan.

The students can use the adsorption equilibria data of different species on a specific adsorbent to evaluate the adsorbent’s selectivity for a given separation. The isosteric heat of adsorption can also be calculated (e.g., employing the Clausius–Clapeyron equation), and its dependence on the adsorbent loading can be studied. Furthermore, since the volumetric unit permits studying two different adsorbents simultaneously, the resulting adsorption equilibrium isotherms can be compared and the students can discuss the influence of the amount adsorbed and isotherm shape on cyclic adsorption separation processes. Finally, it is important to note that the setup built can be focused to specific topical applications like biogas upgrading, which require accurate measurements at pressure ranges lower than 1 bar. For this purpose a highly accurate pressure sensor can be coupled to the unit, after a proper recalibration and correction of its reference volumes.

A low-cost, multisample volumetric apparatus for adsorption equilibrium studies was designed and assembled. A Labview-based software was developed in-house for data acquisition and unit control. The laboratorial apparatus is simple, and its operation is straightforward, offering the possibility of measuring gas adsorption equilibrium isotherms on two adsorbent materials at the same time, between 0 and 20 bar, and over a wide temperature range (303–1373 K).

The operation of the volumetric unit was validated by performing adsorption isotherm recordings and comparing the results with data measured in a gravimetric apparatus. For this purpose, the adsorption equilibria of CO
at 323 K on MIL-53(Al) metal–organic framework and an activated carbon were recorded. The good agreement between the results successfully validates the operation of the volumetric unit.

The volumetric adsorption setup built and described in this work is perfectly adequate for demonstrating the concept of gas adsorption to students. The experimental unit contributes to students’ education and training in adsorption science, introducing to them experimental techniques in this research field. The readout from the setup can be processed to provide good quantitative data of gas uptake by an adsorbent. Through the application of theoretical methods, the setup provides a good introduction to adsorption science to industrial chemistry and chemical engineering students.

Removal of carbon dioxide from natural gas by vacuum pressure swing adsorption
Removal of Carbon Dioxide from Natural Gas by Vacuum Pressure Swing Adsorption
Cavenati, Simone; Grande, Carlos A.; Rodrigues, Alirio E.

A vacuum pressure swing adsorption (VSA-PSA) process is studied for the removal of carbon dioxide in a contaminated stream of natural gas to achieve fuel grade methane.  The adsorbent used was zeolite 13X (CECA) where CO2 is strongly adsorbed.  A Skarstrom-type cycle comprising pressurization with product, feed, countercurrent blowdown, and countercurrent purge was employed.  A mixt. of 60% CH4, 20% CO2 and 20% N2 was used, and two different temps. were evaluated in a single-column VSA-PSA unit.  Under the conditions tested, CO2 was removed to levels lower than 2% as required by fuel grade methane with methane recovery higher than 80% without recycle.  This sepn. process also helps in the CH4-N2 sepn.  A bidisperse (macropore-micropore) model also including distributed energy balances in gas, solid, and column wall considering heat and mass transfer resistance at the gas-solid interface was used to simulate the VSA-PSA behavior and compare with expts.  Also, some scale-up considerations are considered and evaluated by simulations of the process.
Air Drying by Pressure Swing Adsorption
Journal of Chemical Engineering of Japan

Air drying expts. by pressure-swing adsorption (PSA) were carried out by using 2 columns packed with silica gel as adsorbent.  Measurements were also made of batch adsorption of H2O(g) on silica gel to obtain input data for the PSA simulation program.  Exptl. PSA results were compared with this computer simulation.  A good agreement was obtained, and the trend of exptl. results was well explained by simulation for both isothermal and nonisothermal cases.  In the simulation, mass transfer coeffs. 2 or 3 times larger than those estd. conventionally from batch measurement were used to obtain good coincidence.  The mass transfer coeffs. were detd. by a recently developed method for short adsorption and desorption cycle (S. Nakao and M. Suzuki, 1983).  The simulation method is useful in predicting the performance of air drying by PSA.
Oxygen Production by Pressure Swing Adsorption
Oxygen production by pressure swing adsorption

The specific O prodn. capacity and the O recovery of a pressure-swing adsorption (PSA) process for the prodn. of O from air by selective adsorption of N is increased by operating the process at a superambient temp.  The higher-temp. operation provides more efficient desorption of Ni from the adsorbent, which more than offsets the detrimental effects of the lower selectivity and capacity of adsorption of Ni from air at the elevated temp.  The concept is demonstrated by evaluating the performance of an 8-step PSA-O process to produce a 90% O product stream at different temps.  Thus, 10% higher O prodn. capacity and 14.5% larger O recovery are obtained by operating the PSA process at 60° vs. its performance at 30°.  The PSA process and its performance data from a pilot plant are discussed.
Carbon Dioxide Capture by Indirect Thermal Swing Adsorption using 13X Zeolite
Carbon dioxide capture by indirect thermal swing adsorption using 13X zeolite
Merel, J.; Clausse, M.; Meunier, F.

The performance of an indirect temp. swing adsorption process for CO2 removal from N2 using 13X zeolite was investigated.  Breakthrough expt., with a 10% CO2-N2 mixt., were performed showing that thanks to the cooling, the adsorbent capacity is preserved and close to that of an isothermal adsorption.  For the desorption step, CO2 at a concn. of nearly 100% is recovered thanks to the indirect heating and the non-use of purge gas.  During the cycle expts., we obtained 7.9 MJ/kgCO2 for the sp. heat consumption.  This value is slightly higher than amine absorption ones, which is the ref. process for CO2 capture.  However, it has to be taken into account that there is a good potential of energy saving because our process configuration (adsorbent choice, no. of beds, step duration, etc.) was not optimized yet.  Moreover, in scaled-up process, the heat losses are of less importance, which will decrease the sp. heat consumption.  This is confirmed by a first estn., which gives a value of 5.9 MJ/kgCO2.
Activated Carbon Honeycomb Monolith – Zeolite 13X Hybrid System to Capture CO

Activated carbon honeycomb monolith - Zeolite 13X hybrid system to capture CO2 from flue gases employing Electric Swing Adsorption
Ribeiro, R. P. P. L.; Grande, C. A.; Rodrigues, A. E.

A preliminary study concerning the performance of a new hybrid adsorption bed for flue gas CO2 capture by elec. swing adsorption (ESA) was performed.  The hybrid adsorption bed consisted of an activated C honeycomb monolith with zeolite 13X particles packed inside its channels.  The sorption bed dynamic behavior was evaluated in break-through expts.  The amt. of CO2 adsorbed was double vs. an activated C monolith alone, even when the zeolite content was only 18%.  ESA exptl. cycles were tested.  Purity of 46.6% was obtained while capturing 81.4% of the CO2 fed in a 6-step ESA cycle.  The obtained purity means a 5.8 time feed stream enrichment.  Exptl. energy consumption was still high due to mass transfer zone limitations. Adsorption Kinetics and Isotherms: A Safe, Simple, and Inexpensive Experiment for Three Levels of Students
Adsorption Kinetics and Isotherms: A Safe, Simple, and Inexpensive Experiment for Three Levels of Students
American Chemical Society and Division of Chemical Education, Inc.

Adsorption kinetics and isotherms are taught to chem. and engineering students and are important to understanding operations such as water pollution treatment, yet many students do not have the opportunity to perform a hands-on expt. that demonstrates the theory in a practical and tangible way.  This paper describes an expt. that is inexpensive, safe, and visually conclusive and can be used for a variety of student audiences: non-science and non-engineering students, first-year engineering students, and upper-level engineering students.  Adsorption kinetics and isotherms were examd. through the dyeing of fabric.  All students obsd. the dyed water becoming colorless, while the adsorbent darkens.  Students used the spectrophotometer to measure dye concns. as a function of time and found that the data followed the first-order process they learned in calculus.  Upper-division students noted a systematic error in the first-order model and detd. that a second-order model fits the process much better.  Students in upper-level courses also developed a procedure to collect data and fit it to isotherms.  Data can be obtained at different temps. for a complete picture of the process.

The study of adsorption phenomenon is one of the most relevant and traditional phys. chem. expts. performed by chem. undergraduate students in lab. courses.  In this article, we describe an easy, inexpensive, and straightforward way to exptl. det. adsorption isotherms using pieces of filter paper as the adsorbent and an org. dye the as the adsorbate.
Fernandes, Daniel L. A.; Xavier, Ana M. R. B.; Portugal, Ines; Da Silva, Francisco A.; Silva, Carlos M.
Journal of Chemical Education, Dept. of Chemistry

A simple, low-cost expt. that illustrates the adsorption process from soln. and its quant. treatment is presented.  The system consists of glass microspheres, the adsorbent, and aq. solns. of an org. dye, crystal violet (CV).  The intense color of these solns. allows the students to visualize the propagation of the concn. profiles along the column.  With this expt. the students det. the adsorption isotherm, measure percolation parameters from breakthrough curves and simulate the column using approx. and exact models.  Conclusions are drawn by comparing exptl. data and the theor. data.

Experimental and Theoretical Studies of Supercritical Methane Adsorption in the MIL-53(Al) Metal Organic Framework
Experimental and Theoretical Studies of Supercritical Methane Adsorption in the MIL-53(Al) Metal Organic Framework
Lyubchyk, Andriy; Esteves, Isabel A. A. C.; Cruz, Fernando J. A. L.; Mota, Jose P. B.

The adsorption equil. properties of supercrit. methane in the large-pore (lp) structure of the MIL-53(Al) metal org. framework were studied exptl. by gravimetric adsorption and theor. by grand canonical Monte Carlo (GCMC) simulation.  The adsorption expts. span a broad range of pressures (0.01-7 MPa) and temps. (303-353 K).  In the mol. simulation work, MIL-53lp(Al) is assumed to have a perfect, rigid lattice, and both fluid-fluid and solid-fluid interactions are modeled using the TraPPE-UA force field.  The adsorption isotherms and isosteric heats of adsorption predicted by GCMC simulation, without any reparametrization of the TraPPE-UA force field parameters, are in good agreement with the exptl. measurements.  The mol. simulations predict that the amt. of methane adsorbed in the porous framework of MIL-53lp(Al) at 298.15 K and 3.5 MPa is 5.79 mol/kg, yielding a methane storage capacity of 132.6 vol./vol. (vols. of stored gas, measured at std. conditions, per storage vol.) for a monolithic block and 107.2 vol./vol. for the theor. limit of a close-packing of uniform spherical particles.  For an isothermal (298.15 K) discharge cycle between 3.5 and 0.136 MPa, the predicted net deliverable capacity is 114.0 (vol./vol.)net for a monolith and 93.1 (vol./vol.)net for a close-packed bed.  If, however, the storage system is operated at 253 K, the net storage capacity of a monolithic block of MIL-53(Al) increases to a value that is very close to the DOE target of 150 (vol./vol.)net.
Adsorption Equilibrium of Carbon Dioxide and Nitrogen on the MIL-53(Al) Metal Organic Framework
Adsorption equilibrium of carbon dioxide and nitrogen on the MIL-53(Al) metal organic framework
Camacho, Barbara C. R.; Ribeiro, Rui P. P. L.; Esteves, Isabel A. A. C.; Mota, Jose P. B.

The single-component adsorption equil. of carbon dioxide (CO2) and nitrogen (N2) on a com. sample of MIL-53(Al) metal org. framework were measured over a pressure range of 0-34 bar at 303 K, 323 K, and 353 K, using a magnetic suspension microbalance.  The adsorption equil. of both gases were characterized by type I isotherms that do not exhibit the guest-induced transition between MIL-53(Al)'s narrow-pore (np) and large-pore (lp) structures that was obsd. on some MIL-53(Al) samples upon CO2 adsorption at the temps. of this study.  The obsd. CO2 loadings at high pressure are consistent with a np-stabilized MIL-53(Al) form that possesses no visible breathing behavior.  The adsorption measurements show that CO2 is preferentially adsorbed over N2, indicating that MIL-53(Al) can be potentially employed in adsorption-based sepn. processes for environmental applications, such as carbon capture from flue gases emitted by fossil-fueled power stations.  The Sips and Toth isotherm models were successfully fitted to the exptl. adsorption data and the corresponding heats of adsorption detd. from the isotherm models.  The adsorption potential theory was also employed to correlate the CO2 and N2 adsorption data, as well as previously detd. methane adsorption data on the same adsorbent.  This approach successfully collapses the adsorption equil. data into a single temp.-independent characteristic curve.
Adsorption of Natural Gas and Biogas Components on Activated Carbon
Adsorption of natural gas and biogas components on activated carbon
Esteves, Isabel A. A. C.; Lopes, Marta S. S.; Nunes, Pedro M. C.; Mota, Jose P. B.

Exptl. results are presented for the adsorption equil. of methane, ethane, propane, butane, carbon dioxide, and nitrogen, as well as natural gas odorants tert-Bu mercaptan and tetrahydrothiophene, on an activated carbon with the desirable characteristics for use in a guard bed for adsorbed natural gas storage, but that can also be applied for sepn. of biogas components, such as carbon dioxide and nitrogen.  The adsorption expts. were performed using both open- and closed-loop gravimetry over the pressure and temp. ranges of 0-9 MPa and 273-325 K, resp.  The two odorants were analyzed at the very low concns. usually found in natural gas (0-25 mg/(N m3)).  The exptl. data were successfully correlated by the adsorption potential theory and collapsed into a single temp.-independent characteristic curve.  This anal. allows for extrapolation of the adsorption data to higher alkanes, for which no exptl. data are available, in order to span the global compn. of a typical natural gas stream.  The adsorption equil. data for methane, carbon dioxide and nitrogen were fitted to the Toth and Sips isotherm models and their isosteric heats of adsorption were detd.  The preferential adsorption capacity for carbon dioxide indicates that the carbon can be used for methane purifn. from natural gas, carbon dioxide sequestration from flue gas, or biogas purifn.
High-Pressure Adsorption Measurements. A Comparative Study of the Volumetric and Gravimetric Methods
High-pressure adsorption measurements. A comparative study of the volumetric and gravimetric methods
Belmabkhout, Y.; Frere, M.; De Weireld, G.

The authors propose a comparative study between a volumetric app. and a gravimetric one, which were developed for the acquisition of high-pressure adsorption isotherms.  The volumetric app. is able to perform measurements in the temp. range 278-323 K and in the pressure range 0-4000 kPa.  The authors provide a complete report on the exptl. errors due to the mass balance calcn. based on pressure-vol.-temp. measurements.  The same anal. study was achieved for a gravimetric app. (temp. range: 223-393 K, pressure range: 0-10,000 kPa).  The comparison comments are based on exptl. data obtained for the system: activated C (CENTAUR Chemviron C)-nitrogen.  It appears that for such a system exhibiting quite low adsorbed quantities, important discrepancies may appear if the measurements are not properly achieved.  Minimizing the exptl. errors for the 2 exptl. techniques leads to an av. obsd. deviation (relative error) between the 2 methods equal to 3% in the whole measurement range.

on the 5A Molecular Sieve by a Simple Volumetric Apparatus
Equilibrium isotherms for CO, CO2, CH4 and C2H4 on the 5A molecular sieve by a simple volumetric apparatus
Pakseresht, Saeed; Kazemeini, Mohammad; Akbarnejad, Mohammad M.

Adsorption equil. data for CO, CO2, CH4 and C2H4 on 5A mol. sieve were obtained at (303, 373 and 573) K and at partial pressures up to 1000 kPa.  An accurate and simple volumetric app. was used to measure gas sorption.  The Langmuir and Sips equations were used to correlate the exptl. data.  In spite of the relative simplicity of both isotherms, the correlation between exptl. and theor. data is good.  The Sips equation with three parameters has expected a better fit than the Langmuir isotherm with two parameters.  Based upon the Langmuir equation the enthalpy of adsorption and pre-exponential factor in the van't Hoff correlation were derived for all four gases.

High Pressure Hydrogen Adsorption Apparatus: Design and Error Analysis
High pressure hydrogen adsorption apparatus: Design and error analysis
Qajar, Ali; Peer, Maryam; Rajagopalan, Ramakrishnan; Foley, Henry C.

In the present work, design and operation of a high pressure gas adsorption app. at room temp. and at pressures up to 100 bar are discussed.  A theor. and exptl. error anal. is done to det. accuracy and robustness of the measurements.  For this study, activated carbon was selected as the adsorbent and hydrogen as the adsorbate gas.  A sensitivity anal. was done by taking into account the effects of temp., pressure, vol. and wt. of the sample.  The anal. shows that the vols. of the sample and ref. cells as detd. by helium-free space measurements have significant effect on the accuracy of the adsorption uptake measurement.  For instance, a 0.1% error in the measurement of either vol. led to approx. a 3% error in hydrogen uptake measurement at 298 K and 100 bar.

Experimental Screening of Porous Materials for High Pressure Gas Adsorption and Evaluation in Gas Separations: Application to MOFs (MIL-100 and CAU-10)
Wiersum, Andrew D.; Giovannangeli, Christophe; Vincent, Dominique; Bloch, Emily; Reinsch, Helge; Stock, Norbert; Chang, Jong-San; Llewellyn, Philip L.

A high-throughput gas adsorption app. for the evaluation of adsorbents of interest in gas storage and sepn. applications has been developed.  The app. is capable of measuring complete adsorption isotherms up to 40 bar on six samples in parallel using as little as 60 mg of material.  Multiple adsorption cycles can be carried out and four gases can be used sequentially, giving as many as 24 adsorption isotherms in 24 h.  The app. was used to investigate the effect of metal center (MIL-100) and functional groups (CAU-10) on the adsorption of N2, CO2, and light hydrocarbons on MOFs.

Characterization of Solid and Liquid Sorbent Materials for Biogas Purification by using a New Volumetric Screening Instrument
Characterization of solid and liquid sorbent materials for biogas purification by using a new volumetric screening instrument
Rother, J.; Fieback, T.; Seif, R.; Dreisbach, F.

With the increasing use of biogas as an energy source the need for new materials and methods to purify and clean the corresponding gas mixts. is rising.  In this regard, the application of ad- or absorptive gas purifn. methods has increased significantly over the last years.  For fast and economic evaluation of the potential of different sorbent materials, a new volumetric screening instrument was developed.  First the measuring method and the new instrument design will be described.  This instrument allows ad- and absorption, as well as desorption measurements in a tech. relevant, wide pressure, and temp. range.  It was used for the characterization of common sorbent materials such as activated carbons and zeolite mol. sieves.  Addnl., new substances like metal-org. frameworks and ionic liqs. were analyzed.  Thereby the sorption of CO2, CH4, N2, and H2 was measured.  The obtained data allow the direct comparison of the sorption properties of the different materials, the results of which will be presented in the 2nd part of the paper.
